title: Microsoft Excel 2013 for Beginners - Start Your Excel Journey
headline: Learn the basics of Microsoft Excel 2013 and how to create spreadsheets with this free online Excel course.
description: This free online Microsoft Excel for Beginners training course is the perfect way to start your Excel journey. This course, designed for complete beginners, will teach you how to store numbers, create rules and apply filters using the Microsoft Excel spreadsheet software. Excel is a popular productivity and work management software. Start this free online course today, and let our expert author help you become a spreadsheet master.
courseDescription:
This introductory course on using Microsoft Excel 2013, you'll learn the basics of using Excel, from opening up the software to formatting, to proofing your worksheets, and managing different Excel workbooks. The course starts off with the basics of what Excel is and what’s new in Excel 2013, along with introducing the touch screen interface. Then the course then teaches you about the basics of a spreadsheet layout, using templates and the help menus, and setting Excels options.

Next, the course will teach you about the Excel interface using commands, the Ribbon and Toolbars. You will also learn about the various was of entering and deleting data from a spreadsheet. The course then introduces you to formatting your worksheet from adding themes and cell styles to text wrap and alignment all for visually improving and organizing your spreadsheets. Lastly, the course goes through proofing your worksheets and how to copy, paste, move and manage worksheets between workbooks and within a workbook.

This course is perfect for people just starting their journey in Excel and want to learn the basics about how to use and operate a spreadsheet. In this detailed course your expert instructor will take you through the essential things you need to learn when getting started in MS Excel 2013. So start this course today, and by the end of the week you’ll have developed new skills for using Excel with confidence.

Start Course Now

  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.

Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:

  • : a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked , posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed : a physical version of your officially branded and security marked in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

All are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison , please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison , you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our pricing, please visit our Pricing Page
slides:
• Upon successful completion of this module the learner will be able to:
    • Identify the new features in Excel 2013 that are not in older versions.

    • Recognize how to use Excel 2013 with a touch screen interface.

• Introduction to Excel 2013

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• What is New in 2013?

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Overview Of Principles

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• The key points from this module are:
  • Excel 2013 is the latest version of Microsoft’s Excel product and Excel is the world’s most popular spreadsheet product.

    Excel every day not only for things like personal finances, but also it’s used in big business, and is really important for business such as finance.

    Excel version older than the 2007 version don’t have the ribbon interface.

    Some of the changes in Excel 2013 are in fact intended to accommodate people that use touch screens

    If you’re trying to use a product like Excel with a touch screen, you do need a certain amount of flexibility in terms of being able to touch the screen accurately

    With Excel 2013, templates do most of the setup and design work for you. Now if you’re creating a spreadsheet for a common type of application, there’s a good chance that Excel 2013 will include a template that you can start to work from.

    A lot of the changes in Excel 2013 relate to charting and some of them are really quite advanced features to do with pivot tables and charts, slices, and the like.

    Now increasingly people are storing data online, as such there are various ways that you can save and share files online in Excel 2013

    You can get access to a good document to help you with the use of touch in Office 2013 from the Excel Help.

    You can get help by pressing the F1 key on your keyboard.

• Upon successful completion of this module the learner will be able to:
    • Explain the process of creating, opening, saving and using a template workbook in Excel.

    • Identify all the ways in which you can access and navigate the Help menus.

• Starting/Closing Excel; Workbook, Sheets, Cells, Rows, & Columns

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Templates; Creating, Opening, and Saving a Workbook

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Online, Offline, and Contextual Help

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Excel Options

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• The key points from this module are:
  • When creating new Workbooks, you can use templates, which will be downloaded from Microsoft, they have a description and rating to help decide whether to use them or not.

    The general idea of templates is somebody has gone to the trouble of creating the mechanism to make this thing work, and you could take this, maybe adapt the categories to your own requirements and needs.

    Templates a really excellent way of getting you started on setting up a workbook to perform a useful function.

    Many of the templates that are provided are quite complex for a beginner

    When creating a blank workbook its default name is normally book 1 and each worksheet been sheet 1, sheet 2, etc.

    Generally, to access help you click on the question mark (?) in the top right hand corner of excel. It is in the same place on dialog boxes.

    Help in Excel 2013 and all help Office 2013 products is a browser-based system, with back and forward and search.

    Excel 2013 help is very restricted when your offline, and you can choose to look at the offline or online help.

• Upon successful completion of this module you will be able to:
    • Identify how to navigate and use the Ribbon Interface.

    • Recognise how to use keyboard short cuts to access the tabs on the Ribbon.

    • Identify how to add buttons to and customize the quick access toolbar.

    • Discuss the various methods of Backing up, Auto-Recovering and autosaving you’re excel workbooks.

• Ribbon Interface

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Quick Access Toolbar

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Mini Toolbar

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Create Backup Option; Auto-Recover and Autosave

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Upon successful completion of this module you will be able to:
  • The ribbon interface works on a tab interface with the likes of the View tab containing all the view functions and buttons, insert tab containing all the insert functions and so forth.

    You get will additional tabs sometimes, for example charts tab is added when you click on a chart in the workbook.

    All the individual commands in a tab are grouped together for example on the font buttons are grouped in one place on the home tab with a grey line separating it from the group with all of the paragraph buttons.

    Many of the commands on the ribbon have been spaced out a little bit more and arranged a little bit more carefully to allow access on touch devices.

    You can use a set of key tips to navigate and use the commands in the ribbon by pressing the Alt key and then the corresponding keys are displayed beside each tab/command, then press the key for which command you wish to use.

    The Quick Access Toolbar by default has a small number of commands, normally save, undo and redo, but you can add more. It is for quick access regularly used commands.

    The mini tool bar general appears with anything where you enter text, numbers, etc, it gives you away of quickly format without having to go up to the ribbon. It is contextually sensitive meaning it will only appear upon user interaction.

    The principle of the auto-recover and autosave is that excel will ensure your work is saved or copied in case of a power outage, program crash or something that could lose your work.

    By default, Excel sets save auto recovery information every 10 minutes.

• Upon successful completion of this module you will be able to:
    • Recognise the ways in which you can enter data into an excel workbook.
    • Identify how to specify/restrict what type of data can be entered into a cell, row or column.
    • Recognise how to change and setup different date formats for you excel worksheets.
    • Identify how to change and specify different number formats.
    • Recognize the formatting options and methods for text in a cell.
    • Discuss ways to edit and delete data in cells.
    • Recognise how you can use the fill function to create a series.

• Entering Text and Numbers

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Date Formats

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Formatting Cells; Editing and Deleting Data

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Fill

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Flash Fill

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• The key points from this module are:
  • Pressing the enter key after entering data in a cell your selection will be move to the cell below.

    Text is aligned to the left of the cell it is entered in and numbers align to the right of the cell.

    Moving you courser in between the top of two columns, will change the cursor to a line with a double headed arrow, which can click and drag to the right to increase the width of a column.

    Using the formula bar to change the text in a cell is often easier trying to click into the specific places in a cell.

    On the home tab between the alignment and styles group there is a command to select the data types of what can be entered into a cell. Even specifying a type of currency.

    Excel’s date default format is tied to your computers default date format. But it can be change in Excel, suit what format that suits, or even make a custom one.

    A line of # symbols in a cell means the cell doesn’t have enough room to display it’s data, so you need to either widen the cell or wrap the text, for it to display.

    In the format cells dialog box you can set the number of decimal places that come after a number, the currency symbol, or even make the data a scientific number.

• Upon successful completion of this module the learner will be able to:
    • Identify how to add Themes and cell styles to your workbooks, and worksheets.
    • Recognise the various ways you can Insert, delete, hide, and adjust rows and columns.
    • Identify how to change column with and row height to display a cell content clearly.
    • Discuss the three levels of formatting in Excel.

• Themes and Cell Styles

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Inserting, Deleting, Hiding and Adjusting Rows and Columns

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Wrap Text and Alignment

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Merging Cells; Applying Themes and Styles

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Borders

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• The key points from this module are:
  • Themes are a set or group of colours, fonts, graphics etc. that you can use to change how to Worksheet look and feel.

    By default, the office theme is applied to newly made workbooks.

    The themes in Office 2013 are common across the applications of the Office suite.

    When you’re formatting there are basically three levels of formatting and the theme is at the top level of the formatting.

    When you’re formatting a worksheet, when you’re putting in the colors, the fonts, and so on, you can adopt either one of the standard Excel 2013 themes or you can even create a theme of your own

    There are about 20 given themes, but you can browse and download more from Microsoft’s Website.

    A theme applies to the whole workbook while styles affect only cells or a range of selected cells.

    The cell styles have their own groups, such as Titles and headings, Data and models, or number format.

    Changing a theme will affect any styles applied to cells as that theme has its own setting for styles such as headings and titles.

• Upon successful completion of this module you will be able to:
    • Recognize how to use copy, cut and paste and paste special in Excel.
    • Discuss different ways of pasting in Excel.
    • Recognize how to use Excels spell check accurately.
    • Recognize how to set the spellcheck options to suit your needs.
    • Discuss managing your Worksheets, with moving, copying, inserting, deleting and locking sheets.

• Copy, Cut and Paste

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Spell checking

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Moving, Copying, Inserting, Deleting and Locking Sheets; Multiple Worksheets

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• The key points from this module are:
  • The buttons for cut, copy and past are in the home tab in the clipboard group on the far-left side of the ribbon.

    Whether paste will make a column wider, or whether paste will make a row taller, and so on largely depends both on the current situation in terms of what’s on the worksheet you’re working in and on the formatting that you’re using.

    The key board shortcuts, for copy is Ctrl+c, for paste is Ctrl+v, and cut is Ctrl+x.

    In excel paste has far more options than other applications you can paste just, values, or formulas, and may more options.

    The format painter allows you to copy the format of a selection and apply it elsewhere, double clicking on the format painter locks it in, letting you to use it in multiple places.

    You can copy and paste rows and columns, but they will replace the row or column that you are pasting into, unless you right click and select insert copied Cells.

    The paste special dialog box contains all the different ways in which you can paste copied or cut content.
